documents.document: Senate Republicans have tools to repeal Obamacare (reconciliation) and, if needed, to confirm Gorsuch (two speech rule). Will they be used?
To "repair" implies to "preserve." Congress increasingly sounds like it has made peace with Obamacare. https://t.co/jlZI4ZWn8r
Conservative Lawmakers Warn Congress Not to Reinstate Earmarks https://t.co/IhCtHf3Tou via @LRacheldG @DailySignal
More evidence that the two parties are made up of individual senators whose views vary. https://t.co/7Zkl9UmYtU https://t.co/jGxvH9xEEN
It's likely Gorsuch gets 60 once Democrats realize GOP can break filibuster using two speech rule. https://t.co/jb5kWRXpim
Nuclear option not necessary. McConnell has all the tools he needs under existing rules to confirm Gorsuch with 51. https://t.co/jb5kWRXpim
By delaying the effort to repeal Obamacare, Congress makes preserving it more likely. https://t.co/nfhyO0l8KL
Former House Freedom Caucus Chairman on Obamacare: ‘Let’s Repeal It as Quickly as We Can’ https://t.co/KU3RlYhzBb @DailySignal
@greenfield64 omitted an important fact. Rule XIX precludes a Democratic filibuster of Gorsuch if strictly enforced. https://t.co/SrfORsfI8h
How the GOP can steamroll liberal opposition to Neil Gorsuch's confirmation https://t.co/sLltAA6CD0
Trump only called for nuke option if Senate is gridlocked over SCOTUS. Rule XIX precludes minority filibuster here. https://t.co/izNoDzOHYD
This should caution us not to take 51 Senate votes for granted. The GOP is not a monolithic entity. https://t.co/2YzZ6p2g9l via @DCExaminer
@joshHuder Precisely.
They've been on the job for one month now and members of Congress in the House and Senate have yet to vote to repeal Obamacare. Why wait?
Trump only suggested nuclear option if Senate is gridlocked. But the two speech rule precludes gridlock on SCOTUS. https://t.co/KhMqP42wn1
Under current Senate rules, the minority can't stop SCOTUS confirmation if the majority is determined to prevail. https://t.co/fpXvk3IJOm
@MattGlassman312 Small price to pay for SCOTUS confirmation. It is the way Senate ought to work. Allows both sides to size up each other.
@nielslesniewski The parliamentarian does not determine what the Senate rules are. He or she simply advises the Senate on the rules.
@nielslesniewski The only thing that really matters is whether or not the precedent in question explicitly violates the Standing Rules.
@MattGlassman312 A credible threat to strictly enforce the two speech rule during SCOTUS debate yields 60 votes for cloture.
@MattGlassman312 Every time a Democrat forces a 3 am vote, the GOP gets one step closer to confirmation. The GOP could also recess to avoid.
@MattGlassman312 Sure. But if GOP is unwilling to vote at 3 am on day 1 to confirm SCOTUS nom, then not likely to have votes to go nuclear.
@MattGlassman312 Why not? Focus is then on obstruction and 8-10 D members who reject jurisprudence of nominee instead of nuke option and Rs.
@MattGlassman312 If minority tries to increase costs on majority to have quorum, it exhausts speeches earlier, thus hastening confirmation.
@MattGlassman312 Motions burn 1 of 2 speeches. Quorum calls not in order if no business has transpired. Only so much minority can do.
This kind of behavior should be concerning to everyone, regardless of party. It strikes at the heart of our system. https://t.co/aWneCIbJh2
@MattGlassman312 Senate isn't doing much. If determination clearly communicated, approximately one week given current reports of D disarray.
Senate Rule XIX empowers McConnell and company to break SCOTUS filibuster without going nuclear. https://t.co/v2BFS8Ricd
It's concerning that only 22% of Clinton voters reject the notion that the Constitution's meaning somehow changes w… https://t.co/hXvyaOyEmU
At this stage, the tax reform debate should be refocused on identifying underlying fundamentals of the ideal system. https://t.co/dF6AoWJpeq
With attention shifting to the Supreme Court, it's important to acknowledge that Congress still hasn't voted to repeal Obamacare.
@saletan @danpfeiffer Why? The current Senate rules empower the majority to break a SCOTUS filibuster without nuclear option.
@jonathanchait The GOP can overcome a SCOTUS filibuster without going nuclear by strictly enforcing Rule XIX (the two speech rule).
Important to remember that our system was built for conflict. Framers believed intra-gov't conflict protects liberty https://t.co/zvghnqlh87
@pkcapitol Current Senate rules empower GOP to end SCOTUS filibuster. Nuke option not needed https://t.co/4CIGHdKigi https://t.co/Uolxfxw4bQ
Good read from @burgessev and @BresPolitico. Rule XIX can make obstruction even more costly. https://t.co/CFAJCKXHO4 https://t.co/Z1g1iCNsB1
Wasn't making "clear break with ingrained rituals and ways of doing business" in DC a major theme of 2016 campaign? https://t.co/J15JtddHwZ
Congressional Republicans eye obscure law as a tool for quickly voiding ACA rules https://t.co/fmRfw208GQ via @modrnhealthcr
The specific policies behind which the GOP unites are much more important than the fact that the party is united. https://t.co/iA2gn5xY5O
Main Street is particularly relevant to politics today given some of the ways in which elites view American people https://t.co/gxxAAKdIi3
Trump Spells the End of the Administrative State. Good. https://t.co/DteaZPoysI @thedailybeast
@washingtonpost @marcthiessen Why use nuclear option when Senate rules already provide a path to confirmation? https://t.co/iYquliDWxx
@siobahnehughes @ByronTau Rule XIX empowers majority to overcome filibuster & confirm SCOTUS nom w/out nuke option https://t.co/wBCqOcdnM0
Blowing up Senate rules to confirm SCOTUS nom isn't necessary. The current rules provide a way to break filibuster. https://t.co/5luSp2ZQ0p
GOP can use existing Senate rules to break Democratic filibuster and confirm SCOTUS nominee if its willing to fight. https://t.co/jyWblMzeu0
@burgessev Rule XIX, if strictly enforced during the SCOTUS debate, will get the Senate to an "up and down vote."
@burgessev Existing rules empower majority to overcome SCOTUS filibuster w/out going nuclear https://t.co/zy6kXeRCEg https://t.co/H7c2DuWnKy
Leaks from the GOP policy retreat are a good reminder that the political parties may not be as unified as we think. https://t.co/cKSzXQ1YIR
In Private, Republican Lawmakers Agonize Over Health Law Repeal https://t.co/praI4sao40
@EdWhelanEPPC @MarkSalter55 This assumption also assumes that the minority's behavior plays no role in what the majority is able to do.
@EdWhelanEPPC @MarkSalter55 GOP cooperation in face of nuclear threat on Perez, Cordray, and McCarthy led to nuke option in November 2013.
@EdWhelanEPPC @MarkSalter55 This is an assumption. If it were true, the filibuster for SCOTUS noms would have already been nuked.
@EdWhelanEPPC @allahpundit Is nuke option then analogous to an activist judge overriding statute (standing rules) with case law (precedent)?
@lindseymburke Does % of Dem/Lean Dem that lists education as top 2017 priority create opportunity to work on ESAs… https://t.co/wmqiZx2irZ
@StevenJDuffield @seanmdav @allahpundit @McCormackJohn I had to save something for the second edition!
@StevenJDuffield @seanmdav @allahpundit @McCormackJohn I wrote book on 01-05 & 2013 filibuster debates. Will be out in fall from @UofMPress
@seanmdav @allahpundit @McCormackJohn Important point: Once R determination is clear, 8 Ds break and vote for cloture. Defeat is inevitable
@wesleydenton @allahpundit @seanmdav @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @Heritage The Estrada fight shows that Ds can threaten Rs with retaliation.
@wesleydenton @allahpundit @seanmdav @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @Heritage That assumes Senate GOP has votes to go nuclear.
@allahpundit @seanmdav @McCormackJohn I don't see why too clever. It literally works. Members can only speak for so long. Just need to fight
@allahpundit @seanmdav @McCormackJohn As for Garland no Senate D expected Trump to win. They thought talking point of obstruction was better
@jiwallner @wesleydenton @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @allahpundit @Heritage In end, it was a surprise. Both sides expected other to blink
@jiwallner @wesleydenton @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @allahpundit @Heritage Thought it would work on DC Circuit. But no real debate before
@jiwallner @wesleydenton @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @allahpundit @Heritage this was enough to confirm Perez, Cordray, NLRB, et al.
@jiwallner @wesleydenton @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @allahpundit @Heritage Every time Ds threatened to go nuclear some Rs voted for cloture
@wesleydenton @McCormackJohn @conncarroll @allahpundit @Heritage threat of going nuclear worked to compel Rs to compromise in months before
@SenateMajLdr is correct. Majority doesn't need nuke option to break SCOTUS filibuster. See: https://t.co/K9AfqRHAdT https://t.co/bBbhBx9VH2
The description of Stage 4 here is spot on. https://t.co/3C7LyijEVH
Closed-door GOP discussion about Obamacare affirms claim that delaying repeal is a bad sign. https://t.co/dt5S9ZaKEI https://t.co/3NP0WzH5Vc
Great read from @newcriterion and its series on populism. https://t.co/lhczPs8WxQ
@mattyglesias I documented similar cooperation between Senate Rs and Ds in my book, The Death of Deliberation. https://t.co/5gnAE5BQdD
Good read from @mattyglesias. Level of cooperation between Senate GOP and Obama in his first term often understated. https://t.co/swS1fhpm4v
Democrats are much less supportive of Trump’s Cabinet than the GOP was of Obama’s https://t.co/swS1fhpm4v via @voxdotcom
@hughhewitt It’s remarkable what you can do with the Senate’s current rules. No need to resort to calling for the filibuster to be nuked.
@jiwallner @mikeallen @axios Working link to paper detailing how a majority can break a SCOTUS filibuster: https://t.co/q9OYgPOAzZ
@nielslesniewski Senate rules empower a majority to end SCOTUS filibuster w/out nuke option. https://t.co/q9OYgPOAzZ https://t.co/0VgrNwb8fQ
Nuking the Senate isn't necessary. Current rules empower majority to break a SCOTUS filibuster and confirm nominee. https://t.co/bv23W7WtjE
@mikeallen Current Senate rules empower a majority to end filibuster w/out nuke option. See https://t.co/fTE6FJJOJh https://t.co/R0mEHZfVAU
@hillhulse The most important distinction: executive actions that violate separation of powers vs those that do not. https://t.co/l4vuV6dEna

@WardDPatrick @burgessev @realDonaldTrump @seanhannity @SenateMajLdr That’s not needed. Rule XIX empowers majority to end SCOTUS filibuster.
Latest replacement plan floated by some Senate Rs doesn't repeal Obamacare. Instead, it locks it in. https://t.co/dt5S9ZaKEI @DailySignal
Congressional Delay Threatens Obamacare Repeal https://t.co/dt5S9ZaKEI @DailySignal
@seanmdav Also, only the people are sovereign. States are not sovereign. States exercise authority delegated to them by the people.
Current rules allow Rs to break a D SCOTUS filibuster. Detailed here: https://t.co/3XkdawP7st https://t.co/9i4p0OldZm @kristinapet @peterwsj

"Novels try to capture eternal human truths — to ground them in the specific." In praise of literary conservatives https://t.co/CBdamIBjiW
Longer Senate sessions makes it easier to use the two-speech rule to end SCOTUS filibuster. https://t.co/fTE6FJJOJh https://t.co/awlHlOIYtK
Good sign from Senate Republicans. A deliberative process is the only way things get done & that takes time. https://t.co/awlHlOIYtK
@Heritage scholars outline policy solutions that improve education, create jobs, and reduce health care costs here… https://t.co/KhaputAyvl
@joshHuder Absolutely. Appreciate the back and forth. It's an important, and confusing, topic.
@joshHuder It set the stage. Then threats to go nuclear followed. Then another try at invoking cloture. But that time it didn't work.
@joshHuder Correct. My point is that the threat was expected to work. When it didn't, then they went nuclear.
@joshHuder And Ds had no reason to think it wouldn't work again in November because here was no process, no discussion of issue.
@joshHuder Because he didn't need to. His tactic of threatening the nuke option was working up until November.
@joshHuder Rs blinked on Perez, McCarthy, Cordray, & NLRB when Ds threatened nuke option earlier in 2013.
@joshHuder And after November 21 he didn’t have to because Rs didn’t blink and Ds went nuclear. And two-speech rule wasn’t necessary.
@joshHuder Because up until November 21 he didn’t have to. Rs blinked and confirmed noms in face of threat to go nuclear.
